appearances.snippet: here with me is ohio senator bernie moreno senator great to have you on tonight. venezuela, the interim authority there is turning over 30 to 50 million barrels of oil to the united states and that it will be sold at market price and the president said the money will be controlled by him for the benefit of the american people but to the venezuelan people first. this could be up to about $2.8 billion. heads are exploding on the other networks tonight because of like trump is taking the oil. this is just a play for his oil friends and the petro chemical industry. your response tonight? >> well, first of all, let's give a huge shout-out to the military that did an amazing job on saturday so we can't forget how incredible that was and president trump's courage to actually green light that mission which was flawless. in terms of the oil, the days of america doing these things our taxpayer expense is over. we deserve to be reimbursed for the cost that it took financially to free venezuela. and, look, i think the left is losing their minds for one simple reason. destabil

appearances.title: Washington Journal 01/09/2026 : CSPAN : January 9, 2026 6:59am-9:00am EST
appearances.snippet: we think we have a skeleton of a deal, said senator bernie moreno, ohio republican who has been leading bipartisan senate talks. that skeleton still needs meet on its bones, but the group of 12 senators, six republicans and six democrats, helps to solidify a deal and introduced legislation next week, then sell it to their broader party caucuses. this group of senators who are working on a bipartisan deal in the senate on enhanced aca subsidies includes senator bernie moreno, susan collins, tim kaine, senator hassan, and senator king. these senators, a group of 12 -- those are some of them -- who are working on a bipartisan approach to the aca subsidies after it is approved in the house yesterday -- was approved in the house, that would not pass in the senate. 17 republicans joined democrats yesterday in the house to pass it in that chamber. your reaction to republican defections on aca subsidies and war powers. greg in montana, democratic call. caller: hello, thank you. i wanted to just say, i think i am happy with both votes. i think it might be a sign they are starting to cooperate a

appearances.snippet: she's kind of leading the charge over in the senate and bernie moreno as well. so i think it's possible that something sort of comes together. it's going to have to be led in the senate. and then, you know, it will be a matter of of if the house takes it up and if they can move something forward. the house is on a very different track. of course, they they want to do another reconciliation package on health care, which is sort of a whole other can of worms. yeah. but, you know, they are focused more on getting money directly to the people. that's sort of what trump has been talking about as well. but the problem with some of those things is that doesn't help people right now, and that doesn't help the americans that are struggling and are going to see their insurance premiums rise in the immediate. that's that's just really not going to be a viable solution. >> yeah. and we are seeing those those credits expire today. so those impacts start right now. ariel hixson, julie roginsky and annelise keller, thank you so much. happy new year to all of you. next, new dea

appearances.title: Worldwide Exchange : CNBC : January 8, 2026 5:00am-6:00am EST
appearances.snippet: republican senator bernie moreno, who's been at the center of these talks, said the group wants to finalize next few weeks. >> i think we're in the red zone. i think we're close to a deal. i think the framework is basically agreed upon. we have to resolve what we're going to do on on how we can assuage some of our colleagues concerns. but i think we're there now. >> there are still several sticking points, most notably whether to include language in the bill that explicitly bars federal funds for being used to pay for abortions. trump actually urged his party to have some flexibility on this issue, but many republicans are doubling down, remaining firm that this requirement needs to be in there. republicans are also insisting that any compromise expand the use of health savings accounts and ensure that everyone is paying something for their premiums, if only a small amount. so no more $0 premiums. now, the tax credits did end last year, but if this bill were to pass, lawmakers say they would reopen the health care exchanges and allow people to reenroll. but, frank, we've still got a very lo

appearances.title: Closing Bell : CNBC : January 7, 2026 3:00pm-4:01pm EST
appearances.snippet: still, you saw ohio senator bernie moreno going on social media this afternoon to say, i will introduce legislation in the senate to codify this into law. so some quick reaction there on capitol hill, this idea, scott, it's been gaining traction in the president's maga base for some time now. the late charlie kirk pitched it publicly over the summer as a way for the president to deliver on affordability for young trump voters. and in an analyst report this afternoon, td cowen says we will be watching if this shifts from a forward focused ban to the required divestiture of existing single family home portfolios. populists in both parties have sought divestitures in the past through legislation, though it's never gained traction. scott, back over to you. >> all right. thank you very much for that. reporting from the white house. now let's bring in cnbc contributor, senior associate dean for leadership studies at the yale school of management, jeffrey sonnenfeld. it's good to have you join us. i'm curious, your reaction, first and foremost to both of these posts today. >> well, scott, than

appearances.title: The Weeknight : MSNOW : January 12, 2026 4:00pm-6:00pm PST
appearances.snippet: his decision to take a leading role in the politically fraught health care negotiations, senator bernie moreno one of trump's best known slogans. putting america first means putting americans first, he said. people are being affected and i want to help the people who need help. that's what we should be doing. >> it smells like a midterm election. it smells like the midterms. maybe, maybe. >> do you got a midterm. >> election in your pocket? >> often said where you stand depends on where you sit. and i think there are a lot of my house republican colleagues. remember, 17 voted for the clean extension last week, which i was very happy about. but let's just say it was not a coincidence that a lot of those 17 are in very vulnerable seats and see what's been happening for the past year. look, we all know the republicans are completely disingenuous when it comes to this issue. this is the same crowd that was pushing repeal and replace for well over a decade, some 15 years. they held over 63 votes to repeal obamacare, even in the so-called big beautiful bill this past summer. let's not forget a reaso

appearances.title: Squawk Box : CNBC : January 15, 2026 6:00am-9:00am EST
appearances.snippet: banking committee, committee, subcommittee chair lumos and my, my colleagues bernie moreno and senator made an enormous amount of progress. there's still some sticking points, and there's a number of amendments and things being kicked around that i think can potentially resolve those. but the key here is we've got to have a framework that creates certainty, that allows for the innovation and at the same time keeps our banking industry healthy and intact. and i think there's going to be a path through that. but it's very complex and it's going to take a while. >> well, let's get into the weeds just for a second. so this is what brian armstrong says that he's raising his objections over. and we may have to explain some of this to the audience. the first is he believes that this effectively would erode the cftc's authority, making it, as he says, quote, subservient to the sec, that the bill would do that. the second is he believes that it gives the government, quote, unlimited access to investors financial records. and the third piece is that he believes that this draft amendment effectiv
